title: Visual Representations of the Third Plague Pandemic
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Visual Representations of the Third Plague Pandemic," aims to conduct a historical and anthropological analysis of the global network of visual representations during the timeframe of 1855-1959. With a death toll of 12,000,000, the Third Plague Pandemic had a significant impact on various regions including China and Japan, India, Africa, and South and North America.

Utilizing photography as a key technology influence, the project will focus on the built environment, civil disturbance and public order, death, corpses, burial, as well as race, class, and discrimination. The research team will consist of a principal investigator and three postdoctoral researchers working full-time to explore the visual narratives and cultural responses to the pandemic across different regions.

Through the analysis of visual materials, the project aims to uncover how the pandemic was represented and interpreted in diverse cultural contexts, shedding light on the complex interplay between visual culture and historical events. By examining the role of photography in shaping public perceptions and responses to the pandemic, the project seeks to contribute to a deeper understanding of the sociocultural dynamics of global health crises.

Overall, this project will provide valuable insights into the ways in which visual representations can inform our understanding of past pandemics and their lasting impact on societies worldwide.
